thread.title: Rap artist seeks ‘real emotion that’s in the words’
thread.title_full: Rap artist seeks ‘real emotion that’s in the words’

title: Rap artist seeks ‘real emotion that’s in the words’
text:
Rap artist seeks ‘real emotion that’s in the words’ Ed Peaco, For the News-Leader 5:04 p.m. CDT October 15, 2015 Rocky Young CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
At the end of the live production of “The Mystery Hour” last month at the Gillioz Theatre, rap artist Rocky Young picked up a mike and faced the audience of the show that brands itself as “cool, but not too cool.” 
Young struck a tone that fit the occasion, delivering rhythmic, snaking lines and a message of goodwill, building to a simple statement: 
“I just want the best for my fellow human beings.” 
Young said that, after the show, some people who didn’t know his music told him they were surprised to hear such a sentiment coming from a rapper. “I think that’s why people have taken a liking to me in Springfield,” he said. “I just want to be a voice for people who don’t have an outlet.” 
Like many songwriters, he uses his art to work through personal challenges while intending to engage listeners. Young, born in Chicago and raised in Cassville, dabbled in rap during middle school but fully embraced it just two years ago. This decision has created a conflict that he explores in music. 
Should I quit school, really chase this dream full time? 
I can’t let my family down, but it’s killing me inside. 
“I was going to school full time, working full time and trying to do music full time. I had to cut out one of the three,” said Young, who had been studying entertainment management at Northwest Arkansas Community College, Missouri Southern State University, and most recently Missouri State University. For more information, listen to “Blue Dream.” 
During the year since he left MSU, he collaborated with acts from Los Angeles and Dodge City, Kan., on the Can’t Sleep Tour, produced an album of original work and made two television appearances. 
Even with these accomplishments, he often feels unsettled, as set forth in “Survivor’s Remorse” — 
There's so much I wanna say, but even more I bottle up. Outside looking in, it's like I got it all figured out. Reality my biggest weakness is my self doubt. 
Conversely, skeptics and detractors seem to toughen him up. 
Love to hate when they see you doing better for yourself. 
Hate to love cause they really just disgusted themselves. 
I'm the author of my own book. I'm just giving back what the game took. 
Look him up on SoundCloud for details. 
Young described a creative cycle starting with experience and strong feeling, proceeding to words, which in turn deploy emotions during performance. Young said he’s a stickler for factuality and truth in his work. He insists on writing without deviating from the details of the source experience, down to the color of the shirt he was wearing, he said. 
In performance, the goal is to bring out “the real emotion that’s in the words,” he said. 
Young will be performing Saturday at Billiards of Springfield in an evening of multiple bands to raise funds for Glo Community Center. For this show, Young will be working for the first time with a live band, the indie group Histories. 
“It’ll be a step up for sure. Live instruments are automatically better,” he said. 
Ed Peaco writes about locally grown Ozarks music for the News-Leader. Contact him at 417-413-9029 or EdPeaco@gmail.com 
Want to go? Rocky Young 
Saturday: Glo Community Center benefit show, Billiards Blue Room, 541 St. Louis St., with Histories, Call Me Beta, Bike Crimes, Vicious Skin, Those Dirty Eyes and Suzi Trash, Information: glocenter.org 
Oct. 24: The Outland, 326 South Ave., with Histories Read or Share this story: http://sgfnow.co/1LwnNjJ MORE STORIES
